Article.ArticleTitle: Catalytic ozonation mechanisms of Norfloxacin using Cu-CuFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>.

AbstractText: As an easily recoverable, environmentally friendly and cost-effective catalyst, CuFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> is a promising candidate for the catalytic ozonation of antibiotics in wastewater. However, its catalytic activity is restricted due to its limited active sites and low electron transfer efficiency. In this study, cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) and Cu<sup>0</sup> were doped with CuFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> to introduce more O<sub>V,</sub> providing more active sites and improving electron transfer efficiency. Experimental results show that the optimum removal efficiency of the catalytic ozonation of Norfloxacin (NOR, a widely used antibiotic) using CTAB doped with Cu-CuFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> as the catalyst is 81.58% with a first-order reaction kinetics constant of 0.03967 min<sup>-</sup><sup>1</sup>. The associated O<sub>3</sub> and catalyst dosages are 2.72 mg·L<sup>-1</sup> and 0.1 g·L<sup>-1</sup>, respectively, which are 1.63 times and 2.22 times higher than those in an equivalent O<sub>3</sub> system. O<sub>V</sub> can provide generation sites for surface hydroxyl groups and trigger ·O<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> and <sup>1</sup>O<sub>2</sub> as the main active oxygen species. The synergistic redox cycles of Fe<sup>2+</sup>/Fe<sup>3+</sup> and Cu<sup>0</sup>/Cu<sup>2+</sup> accelerate electron transfer efficiency. The possible degradation pathways of NOR are identified as defluorination, naphthyridine ring-opening and piperazine ring-opening. In summary, this work proposes a new strategy for the modification of CuFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> catalysts and provides new insights into the catalytic ozonation mechanisms for NOR removal.
